hints_html:
This is a Riemann sum problem. Try isolating a factor of \(\frac{1}{n}\)

The values should look like

\(\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n}\)

\(\displaystyle x_{i} = \frac{i}{n}\)

and so

\(\displaystyle a = 0\)

See if you can determine the rest of the values.
hints_latex: This is a Riemann sum problem. Try isolating a factor of $\frac{1}{n}$

The values should look like

$\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n}$

$\displaystyle x_{i} = \frac{i}{n}$

and so

$\displaystyle a = 0$

See if you can determine the rest of the values.
hints_raw:
This is a Riemann sum problem. Try isolating a factor of <math> \frac{1}{n} </math>
The values should look like

<math> \displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n} </math>

<math> \displaystyle x_{i} = \frac{i}{n} </math>

and so

<math> \displaystyle a = 0  </math>

See if you can determine the rest of the values.
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
Notice that our question is equivalent to

\(\lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}} = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{n} \cdot \frac{i^{4}}{n^{4}}\)

The values for the Riemann sum look like

\(\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n} = \frac{b-a}{n}\)

\(\displaystyle x_{i} = 0 + \frac{i}{n} = \frac{i}{n}\)

and so

\(\displaystyle a = 0\)

and so with the above in the \(\Delta x\), we can deduce that

\(\displaystyle b = 1\)

and our function should be

\(f(x) = x^{4}\)

Hence, we have

\(\lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}} = \int_{0}^{1}x^{4}\, dx\)

completing the question.
sols_latex:
Notice that our question is equivalent to

$\lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}}  = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{n} \cdot \frac{i^{4}}{n^{4}}$

The values for the Riemann sum look like

$\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n} = \frac{b-a}{n}$

$\displaystyle x_{i} = 0 + \frac{i}{n}  = \frac{i}{n}$

and so

$\displaystyle a = 0$

and so with the above in the $\Delta x$, we can deduce that

$\displaystyle b = 1$

and our function should be

$f(x) = x^{4}$

Hence, we have

$\lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}}  = \int_{0}^{1}x^{4}\, dx$

completing the question.
sols_raw:
Notice that our question is equivalent to

<math> \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}}  = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{n} \cdot \frac{i^{4}}{n^{4}}  </math>

The values for the Riemann sum look like

<math> \displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n} = \frac{b-a}{n} </math>

<math> \displaystyle x_{i} = 0 + \frac{i}{n}  = \frac{i}{n}</math>

and so

<math> \displaystyle a = 0  </math>

and so with the above in the <math> \Delta x </math>, we can deduce that

<math> \displaystyle b = 1  </math>

and our function should be

<math> f(x) = x^{4} </math>

Hence, we have

<math> \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}}  = \int_{0}^{1}x^{4}\, dx  </math>

completing the question.
statement_html: Express \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}}\) as a definite integral. Do not evaluate this integral.
statement_latex:
Express $\lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}}$ as a
definite integral. Do not evaluate this integral.
statement_raw: Express <math> \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}} </math> as a definite integral. Do not evaluate this integral.
